Comment: Guess who's back for Round 5!? It's the battered, ancient little handheld chess program Star Chess, which has bleeping red lights in every place imaginable! Time for Star Chess' revenge!
The French Defence.
Main line French.
Main line French.
Star Chess initiates the Advance Variation, sometimes considered premature but perfectly playable and theoretically OK.
The usual move to undermine White's pawn centre.
An IM told me recently that this knight's place is on h6, which has always felt slightly unnatural to me. Time to test his advice.

With a whirr of discomfort, White played a move that shocked me. Sacrificing queen for bishop and rook! Why!?
?!?!?!?!?!? Even more unexpected. Can anyone shed light on this?

How many checkmating threats did I need to create before the game was...drawn. Star Chess performed a little self-satisfied beep. In my hurry to create checkmating threats I had managed to get my queen trapped in a web of my opponent's rooks, knight and pawns. The score is 3 to fatcat2, 2 to the Computers - this isn't over yet, my silicon friends...
